titlepage.titleproper: A Guide to the Dandridge Spotswood Papers, 1585-1939
titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
the Library of Virginia 24974

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dandridge Spotswood. Papers, 1585-1939. Accession 24974. Personal papers collection , The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Virginia.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Martha D. D. Spotswood, Petersburg, Virginia, 30 June 1958.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Dandridge Spotswood was born 17 May 1872 in Petersburg, Virginia to William F. Spotswood (1827-1895) and Isabella Matoaca Dunlop Spotswood (1848-1922). He attended Pantops Academy near Charlottesville, Virginia, Hampden-Sidney College from 1893 to 1896, and Cornell University of Michigan. An industrial and mining engineer, Spotswood spent much of his career in New York and travelling about the United States and Europe. In 1924, he returned to Petersburg and devoted himself to history and genealogy. Spotswood died 27 November 1939 in Petersburg, and was buried in Blandford Cemetery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: Papers, 1585-1939, of Dandridge Spotswood (1872-1939) of Petersburg, Virginia, consisting of abstracts, extracts, and transcripts of agreements, bills of lading, commissions, deeds, genealogical notes, judicial records, letters, military orders, and promissory notes concerning the history of Virginia and of the United States. Subjects include but are not limited to: Virginia history from the 17th to the 20th century; United States history from the 18th and 19th centuries, including the American Revolution, the War of 1812, the Mexican War, and the Civil War; history of California, Mississippi, Missouri, North Carolina, and Tennessee; the United States Navy; agriculture, genealogy, shipping, social life and customs, and tobacco. Prominent correspondents include: Aaron Burr (1756-1836), Jefferson Davis (1808-1889), Andrew Jackson (1767-1845), Stonewall Jackson (1824-1863), Thomas Jefferson (1743-1826), Philip Kearny (1815-1862), Robert E. Lee (1807-1870), Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865), Alexander Spotswood (1676-1740), Alexander Spotswood (1746-1818), Benjamin Stoddert (1751-1813), John Tyler (1790-1862), and George Washington (1732-1799). Families mentioned prominently are the Dunlop family, the Spotswood family, and the Dunlop family. Refer to the on-line finding aid for complete list of items and correspondents. Items 138-146 are original documents.

Letter, 6 July 1839, John B. Davis, Genito, [Powhatan County, Virginia], to Dandridge Spotswood, Petersburg.

did.physdesc: 2 leaves, one original and one typewritten copy.

did.unittitle: Letter, 3 April 1905, Robert M. Dunlop to William B. McIlwaine of Petersburg.
did.physdesc: 2 leaves, one original and one typewritten copy.

did.unittitle:
Extract,
1585-1586, from The First English Settlement in America: Ralph Lane's Colony on Roanoke Island from Richard Hakluyt.
Court record, 17 September 1627, James Citty, concerning Archers Hope. copied from The Cradle of the Republic, p. 148.
Letter, 25 March 1640, Francis Wirt to unknown recipient.
Letter, 10 August 1678, Richard Clark[?] of London to Ruth Tiplady of York County, Virginia.
Letter, 26 February 1683, unknown correspondent to Father Haasmanden of Virginia. Back of copy contains miscellaneous notes.
Letter, 12 February 1686, from unknown correspondent to unknown recipient. Copied from the Virginia Magazine of History and Biography, volume 25, p. 251.
Letter, 5 April 1687, William Fitzhugh to Thomas Harris of London.
did.physdesc: 1 leaf, and 2 p., one typewritten and one handwritten copy.

did.unittitle: Letter, 9 November 1693, Charles Rodes to Sir John Rodes.
Letter, 26 January 1699/1700, [Governor] Francis Nicholson, James City [Jamestown], to vestry of Petsworth Parish, Gloucester County, Virginia.
Order, 21 February 1699/1700, in regard to a pirate, Governor's Council.
Letter, 16 July 1705, William Richardson to Messrs. Perry and Cowper[?].
Letter, 26 [January?] 1748, unknown correspondent in Louisbourg, [Cape Breton, Canada], to unknown recipient.
Letters, 1750, from [Thomas, Lord?] Fairfax to Guy Broadwater of Frederick County, Virginia, concerning surveying.
Letter, 5 July 1758, unknown correspondent to "George."
Letter, 25 December 1762, Thomas Jefferson to [John] Page.
advertisement, 7 December 1767, in Charlotte County, Virginia, for care of poor persons in Cornwall Parish.

Letter, 23 January 1776[?], Benjamin Moore of Dunmore [Shenandoah] County, [Virginia], to Colonel Peter Moore[?] of Martinsburg, [(West) Virginia]. Also includes letter, 29 May 1775, from Isaac Zane to Captain Jacob Haleman[?] of Dunmore County.

Message, 9 July 1775, from David Duncan to the Shawanee. Message signed by John Connally. Also includes letter, 16 December 1811, from James Monroe in Washington D.C., to Joseph Monroe of Charlottesville, Virginia.
Oath of allegiance, 23 April 1779, of Joel Watkins of Charlotte County. Includes biographical note of Watkins and an obituary, January 1820, of Watkins written by John Randolph of Roanoke.
Letter, 8 June 1781, [General George] Weedon[?] to unknown recipient. Miscellaneous notes on back.
Letter, 16 May 1782, John Tyler, in Richmond, to Thomas Jefferson.
Letter, 16 December 1787, John Dandridge of New Kent County, [Virginia], to John Hopkins of Richmond.
Letter, 20 April 1807, A. Spotswood of Spotsylvania County to Edmund Randolph.
Letters, 25 January 1815, Petersburg Volunteers to Anna Matilda Hening of Richmond. Includes a copy of Anna Matilda Hening's reply.

Letter, 13 June 1834, Elizabeth Hamilton of New York, New York, to Mrs. Grant of England. Elizabeth Hamilton was the wife of Alexander Hamilton. Also includes biographical notes on the writer and recipient of the letter.
did.physdesc: 2 leaves, typewritten with copy of letter.

did.unittitle: Letter, 13 April 1844, E. Blair[?] Lee to R. J. Walker. Also includes letter, 30 March 1845, from N. P. Talmadge to unknown recipient.
article, September 1858, from a Petersburg newspaper reprinting the reception of General Nathanael Greene by the city of Petersburg in October 1784.
Remarks, 5 January 1873, by an unknown individual.
Notice, 23 August 1878, concerning the death of William Niblo of New York.

Miscellaneous items, 1830-1937, on Joice Heth, Washington's dry nurse; burning of the home of Donald Mackenzie in Petersburg in 1920; announcement of the death of John Dunlop of London in 1830 and copied in 1937; and genealogical note tracing the ancestry of Robert E. Lee back to Duncan and Robert the Bruce, kings of Scotland.
article, 7 May 1939, from the Richmond Times-Dispatch, concering Major Heros von Borcke.
Notes, n.d., on Dolly Madison, including correspondence.
Letter, n.d., General Stonewall Jackson to General Lafayette McLaws.
Note, n.d., on the Crockett family and description of coat-of-arms.
Reminiscences, n.d., of Mrs. William Henry Wager of Shreveport, Louisiana.
Letter, n.d., Moses Hoge to Thomas Jones of Campbell County, [Virginia]. Includes notes on Jones' son James.
Letters, various dates, regarding medicine and medical treatments. Includes letter from Mildred Roberdeau, Elisha Cullen Dick, and Bushrod Washington.
Letter, n.d., George T. Swann, Brandon Mississippi, to Sarah W. Swann of Cumberland County, [Virginia].
Letter, n.d., from the citizens of Salisbury, North Carolina, to [George Washington].
Letter, n.d., Henry Patillo to unknown recipient. Includes letter, n.d., to Mr. R. Harrison.
Note, n.d., birth and baptism information for Priscilla, daughter of James and Mary Banks.
Note, n.d., on the death of John Randolph of Roanoke.
Letter, n.d., Mary Campbell of Virginia to an unknown recipient.
Letter, n.d., S. C. Bott of Petersburg to "Frances."
Challenge, ca. 1652, to a duel from Thomas Hackett to his son-in-law Richard Denham[?].
Letter, 6 December 1653, Willy[?] Scopes to thomas Willoughby, Lemuel Mason, and John Holmes of Virginia.
Letters, 1717, of Francis Pollock of North Carolina to Governor Charles Eden of North Carolina and Thomas Pollock of North Carolina to Sir Robert Pollock.
Letter, 25 August 1725, William Pepperells [Pepperell] of Massachusetts to Roger Prowse. Includes reply, 8 February 1726, from Prowse.
Letter, 21 January 1735, William Byrd of Charles City County, [Virginia], to Sir John Randolph.
Letter, 6 June 1755, George Croghan of Fort Luther, Pennsylvania, to [George Washington].
Letter, 5 September 1755, Joseph Ball of Stratford, England, to George Washington. Also includes notes on St. Paul's Parish [possibly of Stafford County, Virginia] and its minister William Stuart.
Advertisement, 11 November 1756, for Joseph Borden's stage boat.
Letter, 1 December 1756, John Andrew Henderson of Augusta County, Virginia, to "John."
Letter, 31 May 1769, Philip Lee of Stratford Hall, Westmoreland County, [Virginia], to his brother [possibly Francis Lightfoot Lee].
Letter, 9 June 1770, B. Arnold to B. Douglas of New Haven, Connecticut.
Letter, 28 September 1771, Bernard Moore of Virginia to John Norton of London.
Letter, 12 October 1771, Richard Randolph of "Blanford" to Captain Thomas Munford of the Brig Norborne.

Letter, 23 September 1775, from an unknown correspondent of Fredericksburg, [Virginia], to Messrs. Dixon and Hunter, published in the Williamsburg
Gazette.
Letter, 12 July 1780, Ezra Stiles to Bishop James Madison.
Letter, 7 August 1780, G. Clinton to [Charles or Thomas] Lee.
letter, 2 December 1780, Francis Lightfoot Lee, in Richmond, to Becky Tayloe [Lee?].
Letter, 1782, [Achibald Cary?] to John Sarmavage[?] of Buckingham County, [Virginia]. Includes letter, 6 March 1782, from Archibald Cary to Colonel Davis.
Letter, 1783, George Washington to the Marquis de Lafayette.
Letter, 9 October 1784, Samuel [?] to Jonathan Smith of Philadelphia.
Letter, 22 June 1785, Charles Mynn Thurston to Captain Thomas Baytop. Also includes letter, 2 March 1809, from Jasper S. Clayton to Thomas Baytop.
did.physdesc: 1 leaf, typewritten. Includes a second typewritten copy and a handwritten copy.

did.unittitle: Letter, 12 February 1801, Aaron Burr, Albany, New York, to Thomas Jefferson.
Letter, 18 July 1806, unknown correspondent to an unknown recipient.
General Orders, 29 December 1812, issued by General James Wilkinson.
Letter, 23 May 1814, E. B. Herman, Williamsburg, Virginia, to Rachel Mordecai of Warrenton, North Carolina.
Letter, 25 January 1815, Petersburg Volunteers to Anna Matilda Hening. Includes her reply.
Letter, 15 May 1818, John McCarty to General Armistead T. Mason.
Letter, 25 September 1824, Francis Walker Gilmer in London to John Randolph of Roanoke.
Letter, 6 March 1826, Gilbert Stuart, Boston, [Massachusetts], to unknown recipient.
Letter, 26 May 1839, Major J. D. Graham to Secretary of War Joel Poinsett regarding cadet Philip Kearney.
Letter, 16 September 1852, John Tyler, Jr., to Henry A. Wise.
Letter, 7 November 1856, John Tyler, Jr., to Henry A. Wise.
Letter, 16 April 1862, J. R. Bryan, [Gloucester County, Virginia], to D. C. Randolph.
Letter, 21 July 1863,"A Soldier" to Corbelia Hancock. Also includes a letter from Hancock to her mother.
Letter, 16 December 1865,. R. E. Lee, Lexington, [Virginia], to D.S.C. Cabell in the Senate of Virginia.
Article, 3 February 1879, from the New York Sun reprinting a letter, 27 April 1868, of Horace Greeley.

Notices,
1796-1838, from various Petersburg newspapers containing information on funerals, balls, sermons, sales, and sales of property. Also includes brief biographical information on Donald Mackenzie, Jane Osborne, Jane Jones, Susan Bott, James Campbell, and Edward Stokes.
Letter, n.d., Peter[?] Lyons of Williamsburg to a merchant firm in London.
Letter, n.d., Winfield Scott to Andrew Jackson, and includes Jackson's reply. Also includes some genealogical information on Scott.
Letter, n.d., Baron von Steuben to General George Washington.
n.d., John Bayne, Jr., Edenton, North Carolina, to William Elliott of Williamsburg, [Virginia]..
Notes, n.d.,.
Letter, n.d., to "Tabitha."
